1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• contraindicated in children younger than 2 months due to sulfonamide-induced displacement of bilirubin from plasma protein resulting in an increased risk of kernicterus
  • Acute otitis media: (2 months or older) 50 mg/kg/day (erythromycin component) or 150 mg/kg/day (sulfiSOXAZOLE component, MAX 6 g/day) ORALLY in 3 or 4 divided doses for 10 days; (each 5 mL contains erythromycin 200 mg and sulfiSOXAZOLE 600 mg)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to erythromycin or sulfonamides
  • liver dysfunction or porphyria
  • infants under 2 months of age
  • concomitant administration of astemizole, cisapride, and terfenadine
  • women breast feeding infants less than 2 months of age and pregnancy at term

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• sufonamides should not be used to treat group A streptococcal infections; will not prevent sequelae of rheumatic fever
  • impaired renal or hepatic function
  • patients with myasthenia gravis; risk for exacerbation (erythromycin component)
  • patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, severe allergies or asthma (sulfonamide component)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Erythromycin: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Sulfisoxazole: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Sulfisoxazole: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Diarrhea, Loss of appetite, Nausea, Vomiting
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Ventricular arrhythmia
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Hematologic:Agranulocytosis, Aplastic anemia
  • Hepatic:Abnormal liver function, Hepatic necrosis
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: • Systemic: Erythromcyin acts by inhibition of protein synthesis of susceptible organisms, having no affect on nucleic acid synthesis. Sulfisoxasole is bacteriostatic.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Systemic: Erythromycin ethylsuccinate- Rapidly absorbed; food higher serum concentrations
  • SulfiSOXAZOLE- Rapidly absorbed

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Systemic: Erythromycin- Biliary primarily; Renal: Less than 5%
  • SulfiSOXAZOLE- Renal: 97%, 52% unchanged

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
(suspension) may take without regard to meals; shake well before measuring each dose

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • CBC
  • hepatic function
  • urinalysis with microscopic examination and renal function tests, especially in patients with impaired renal function
  • hearing exam (hearing loss, especially with high doses and renal or hepatic insufficiency)
  • serious infection treatment: sulfonamide blood levels

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
OVERDOSE: Significant toxicity following acute overdose is uncommon. N/V, abdominal pain may occur. ADVERSE EFFECTS: N/V, abdominal pain, diarrhea most common. Cholestasis, sensorineural hearing loss, thrombophlebitis (IV administration), ventricular dysrhythmias/QT prolongation (IV administration) are less common.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated.
  • Abdominal discomfort: Food, milk or an antacid may be given; most effects reverse with drug cessation
  • Monitoring of patient: Baseline ECG, cardiac monitoring as indicated. Renal and hepatic function as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
In general, the macrolide antibiotics are of a low order toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause photosensitivity, diarrhea, loss of appetite, nausea, stomach cramps, or vomiting.
  • Patients with renal or hepatic dysfunction should report signs/symptoms of ototoxicity, as these populations are at increased risk of this adverse effect.
  • Do not use drug with astemizole, cisapride, or terfenadine.
